article_title: Lots of tech talk, but few leading candidates at valley GOP forum
article_text:
Lots of tech talk, but few leading candidates at valley GOP forum

Photo: Scott Strazzante / Photos By Scott Strazzante / The Chronicle Presidential candidate and former IRS Commissioner Mark Everson...

Despite the Republican Party’s business-friendly reputation, the word “technology” has barely been mentioned in the first two Donald Trump-centric debates. Though the tech industry drives the nation’s economy, when leading candidates have passed through Silicon Valley, they’ve been here to hit up techies for cash — not talk policy.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Joe Garofoli
article_metadata.description: Lots of tech talk, but few leading candidates at valley GOP forum  Though the tech industry drives the nation’s economy, when leading candidates have passed through Silicon Valley, they’ve been here to hit up techies for cash — not talk policy.  [...] Palo Alto tech attorney Roger Royse took matters into his own hands and invited all of the GOP candidates to Menlo Park this week to make their pitch — Silicon Valley style — to a hand-picked room of 90 venture capitalists, young libertarians and a few party insiders.  [...] it wasn’t always pretty, like when former Sen. Rick Santorum Skyped in his pitch from the back seat of his darkened car parked on the side of the road in rural Iowa.  The more distressing news for the valley’s image is that the biggest name candidate to show up in person was former New York Gov. George Pataki, who trails two candidates who have quit the race in the polls.  Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul, who has billed himself as the valley’s favorite candidate for his libertarian views, couldn’t muster 15 minutes out of his day for a Skype chat, so he sent along a three-minute canned video that could have been designed for an audience in Dubuque.  [...] minutes from the venture capital mecca of Sand Hill Road, the candidates talked in depth about technology and immigration and taxation — issues that Silicon Valley Republicans have been dying to discuss.  “We can’t have a Republican Party that rejects science,” Pataki said, noting Trump’s stance questioning the value of vaccinations.  Pataki waxed on about how tax credits helped foster the nanotechnology industry in New York, and railed about patent trolls with the venom of a startup founder.  Everson, who is also a former deputy commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, called for immigration reform to help valley companies, including offering a pathway to citizenship for people in this country illegally — a lonely position in the Republican field.  Santorum — a conservative who still wants to dismantle Obama’s Affordable Care Act and ban same-sex marriage, even though the Supreme Court has upheld both — got so giddy in the spirit of the evening that he bragged about sponsoring four bills with liberal California Sen. Barbara Boxer that became law.  Pataki said he “grew up as a technology geek,” fiddling with his ham radio operation on the farm he grew up on.
